abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Agricultural Extension
            Project for Somalia achieved an unsatisfactory overall
            outcome. Following Board approval in September 1987, the
            project got off to a promising start. However, by 1990, the
            security situation in Somalia began to deteriorate. This
            culminated in a civil war which resulted in the ouster of
            the Government in January 1991 and the cessation of project
            activities. The project objectives were therefore partially
            and only temporarily achieved. Infrastructure developed as
            part of the project was nearly completed but subsequently
            destroyed during the war. Bank performance was satisfactory
            throughout the project cycle. Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory, complying with most legal covenants and
            showing continued commitment. However, coordination between
            Bank and Borrower was inadequate. In view of the unstable
            socio-political situation as of the report date of 1994, the
            sustainability of project initiatives is highly unlikely.
            The three major lessons learned are as follows. First,
            collaborative arrangements between key agencies involved a
            project should be worked out at appraisal and their
            finalization should be a condition for loan effectiveness.
            Second, the project financing plan should carefully evaluate
            the Government's ability to meet its counterpart
            funding requirements. The evaluation should occur at
            appraisal, prior to finalizing the financing plan. Third,
            arrangements for collaboration between co-financiers in
            areas such as joint supervision should be firmed up at appraisal.

docna.cdata!:
Somalia - Second Agricultural Extension
            Project : Credit 1794 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Somalia - Second Agricultural
            Extension Project : Credit 1794 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
As agriculture is the major source of
            medium-term growth for the Somalian economy, the Second
            Agricultural Extension Project attempts to support
            agricultural research and extension to increasing
            agricultural productivity.  To this end, the project
            comprises (i) extension services, (ii) training and (iii)
            research.  Within extension services, the project comprises
            improving field services in eight regions of southern
            Somalia by providing technical assistance, vehicles, staff
            housing, operating costs and improvements to headquarters
            facilities.  Under the training component, the project
            includes local and overseas training of extension and
            research staff, constructing and improving training centers,
            and providing adequate equipment and staffing.  Finally, to
            improve agricultural research in the country, the project
            entails a research component.  Within this last component,
            the project intends to establish a research directorate,
            finance a dryland research station at Bonka, and a fund for
            additional adaptive research.  Benefits under the proposed
            project are expected from improving extension and research
            capacities and their impact on agricultural productivity and
            farmers' incomes.
